snippet: Robert Murphy, a Boston lawyer, formed the American Baseball Guild shortly after World War II, but it failed to win adequate support from the players.
abstract: Box Seats article by Robert Weintraub asserts that Marvin Miller deserves all the praise he received after his death for his extraordinary influence as executive director of Major League Baseball Players Assn from 1966 to 1982; but says the road to Miller’s winning free agency for his rank and file was paved by Robert Murphy, Boston lawyer and management expert with the National Labor Relations Board in the aftermath of World War II.
lead_paragraph: Robert Murphy, a Boston lawyer, formed the American Baseball Guild shortly after World War II, but it failed to win adequate support from the players.

headline.main: Failed Baseball Union Helped Pave Way for Success
headline.print_headline: Failed Union Helped Pave Way For Success
